qas.question: In what did Immanuel Kant describe time as a priori intuition that allows humankind to understand sense experience?
What did Kant portray space and time to be?

answers.text: both are elements of a systematic mental framework

qas.question: Kant thought of time as a fundamental part of what?
What type of measurements are used to quantify the duration of events?
What type of measurements are used to quantify the distances between objects?
How did Immanuel Kant describe the mind?
What does the mind allow us to do according to Immanuel Kant?
What framework is the mind a part of?
What did Kant also think of the mind as a part of?

plausible_answers.text: we sequence events, quantify their duration, and compare the motions of objects

qas.question: How do we process with our minds according to Kant?
In what did Immanuel Kant describe measurement as a priori intuition that allows humankind to understand sense experience?

plausible_answers.text: both are elements of a systematic mental framework

qas.question: What did Kant portray measurement and time to be?
Kant thought of measurement as a fundamental part of what?
What type of measurements are used to quantify the number of events?
What type of measurements are used to quantify the distance between measurements?

context: Immanuel Kant, in <a0_0><b10_0>the Critique of Pure Reason<b10_0/><a0_0/>, described time as an <b5_0>a priori intuition<b5_0/> that allows us (together with the other a priori intuition, space) <b6_0>to comprehend sense experience<b6_0/>. With Kant, neither space nor time are conceived as substances, but rather <a1_0><b11_0>both are elements of <b7_0>a systematic mental framework<b11_0/><b7_0/><a1_0/> that necessarily structures the experiences of any rational agent, or observing subject. Kant thought of time as a fundamental part of <a2_0><b8_0><b12_0>an abstract conceptual framework<b12_0/><b8_0/><a2_0/>, together with space and number, within which <b9_0>we sequence events, quantify their duration, and compare the motions of objects<b9_0/>. In this view, time does not refer to any kind of entity that "flows," that objects "move through," or that is a "container" for events. <a4_0><b14_0>Spatial measurements<b14_0/><a4_0/> are used to quantify the extent of and distances between objects, and <a3_0><b13_0>temporal measurements<b13_0/><a3_0/> are used to quantify the durations of and between events. Time was designated by Kant as the purest possible schema of a pure concept or category.
